title: Email Address - Usage Examples
description: Common usage patterns and example configurations for form email input fields

examples.name: Simple Required Email Field
examples.description: Basic email field with required validation and autocomplete
examples.visualDescription: Standard full-width input field with 'Email Address' label, placeholder text, red asterisk for required field, browser autocomplete enabled
examples.useCase: Contact forms, registration forms, simple email collection

attributes.error: Please enter a valid email address.

notes: autoComplete='email' enables browser autofill for email addresses
reqTgl=true adds red asterisk (*) next to label and validates on submit
Email format validated automatically (must contain @ and domain)
Custom error message shows when field is empty or invalid on submit

examples.name: Email Field with FontAwesome Icon
examples.description: Email field with envelope icon and hover color change
examples.visualDescription: Input field with purple envelope icon on left, changes to darker purple on hover, full-width, email validation
examples.useCase: Modern forms, newsletter signups, professional contact forms

attributes.error: A valid email address is required.

notes: iconType must be 'fontAwesome' for FontAwesome icons
icons uses Font Awesome class (fas fa-envelope, fas fa-at, far fa-envelope-open, etc.)
Icon color changes on hover with hvrIcnClr
Email validation is automatic (checks for @ and valid domain format)

examples.name: Email Field with Custom Image Icon
examples.description: Email field using custom image icon instead of font icon
examples.visualDescription: Input field with custom email icon image on left (24x24px), full-width on all devices
examples.useCase: Branded forms, custom-designed forms, theme-specific styling
notes: iconType must be 'image' for custom images
ButtonImage.url should be full URL to image file
ButtonImage.Id is WordPress media library ID
Recommended image size: 24x24px or 32x32px
Image icons don't support color customization (use SVG for color control)

examples.name: Newsletter Signup with Help Text
examples.description: Email field with privacy reassurance help text below input
examples.visualDescription: Standard input with gray help text below: 'We'll never share your email with anyone else', left-aligned, smaller font
examples.useCase: Newsletter signups, subscription forms, privacy-conscious forms

attributes.desctxt: We'll never share your email with anyone else. Unsubscribe anytime.
attributes.error: Please provide a valid email to subscribe.

notes: hlpTxt must be true to enable help text
desctxt contains the help text content
descPoss='bottom' places help text below input
Help text builds trust by addressing privacy concerns
Help text styling controlled by parent tp-form-block

examples.name: Newsletter Form with Inline Submit Button
examples.description: Email field optimized for inline layout with submit button on same row
examples.visualDescription: 70% width email input on left, 28% width submit button on right (2% gap), full-width on mobile, placeholder guides format
examples.useCase: Newsletter signups, footer email collection, hero section CTAs
notes: inpSz.md='68' allows ~30% for submit button plus 2% gap
Submit button needs nxt-btn-inline class to sit on same row
Full-width on mobile (sm/xs) for better UX - button stacks below
Parent tp-form-block layoutType should support inline buttons (nxt-newsstyle-1, nxt-newsstyle-3, nxt-newsstyle-4)
Set columnGap to 0 or small value (4-8px) in parent tp-form-block

examples.name: Email Field with Custom Validation Error
examples.description: Email field with specific error message for business context
examples.visualDescription: Professional contact form email field with custom error: 'Please provide a valid business email address', envelope icon, full-width
examples.useCase: B2B forms, professional contact, business inquiries

attributes.error: Please provide a valid business email address.

notes: Custom error message clarifies expected input (business email)
Briefcase icon reinforces professional context
Placeholder example shows expected format (name@company.com)
Note: Built-in validation only checks email format, not if it's 'business'

examples.name: Email Field with Help Text (Top Position)
examples.description: Email field with instructional help text above the input
examples.visualDescription: Help text appears above input in gray: 'Use your primary email for account recovery', input field below with envelope icon
examples.useCase: Account creation, registration forms, forms needing upfront email guidance

attributes.desctxt: Use your primary email for account recovery and important notifications
attributes.error: Email is required for account creation.

notes: descPoss='top' places help text above input
Useful for instructions users should read before typing
Help text explains why email is important (account recovery)

examples.name: Professional Contact Email with All Features
examples.description: Comprehensive email field with icon, hover state, help text, custom error
examples.visualDescription: Purple @ symbol icon on left, changes to gradient purple on hover, help text below in gray, full-width, professional styling
examples.useCase: High-value contact forms, professional applications, detailed forms

attributes.desctxt: We'll use this email to respond to your inquiry within 24 hours
attributes.error: A valid email address is required so we can respond to your inquiry.

notes: Combines icon, hover color, help text, and custom error message
@ symbol icon (fas fa-at) is modern alternative to envelope
Help text sets expectations (24 hour response time)
Error message is specific and explains why email is needed

commonPatterns.description: Newsletter email field with privacy help text

attrs.desctxt: We'll never share your email. Unsubscribe anytime.

commonPatterns.description: Email field with inline submit button
Email field with FontAwesome envelope icon

validationRules.labelss: Required - Field label displayed to user
validationRules.reqTgl: Optional - Set true for required field (adds asterisk to label, validates on submit)
validationRules.icons: Required if iconType='fontAwesome' - Font Awesome class
validationRules.ButtonImage: Required if iconType='image' - Object with url and Id
validationRules.hlpTxt: Optional - Must be true to enable help text
validationRules.desctxt: Required if hlpTxt=true - Help text content
validationRules.error: Optional - Custom error message (shown on validation failure)

warnings: ‚ö†Ô∏è PARENT REQUIRED: nxt-email-field MUST be placed inside tp-form-block (ancestor requirement)
‚ö†Ô∏è ICON TYPE: iconType must be set before icons or ButtonImage will work
‚ö†Ô∏è AUTOMATIC VALIDATION: Email format validated automatically (must contain @ and valid domain)
‚ö†Ô∏è INLINE BUTTON: For inline submit button, use inpSz ~68-70% and add nxt-btn-inline class to submit button
‚ö†Ô∏è HELP TEXT: hlpTxt must be true for desctxt to display
‚ö†Ô∏è STYLING: Label, input, button styling controlled by parent tp-form-block (lblClr, inpClr, etc.)
‚ö†Ô∏è ERROR MESSAGE: Custom error message only shows when reqTgl=true and email is empty/invalid on submit
‚ö†Ô∏è PLACEHOLDER vs LABEL: Both are useful - placeholder guides format, label identifies field purpose
‚ö†Ô∏è RESPONSIVE WIDTH: inpSz uses md/sm/xs breakpoints - always set mobile (xs) to 100% for better UX
‚ö†Ô∏è ICON COLOR: icnClr and hvrIcnClr only work with iconType='fontAwesome', not with image icons
‚ö†Ô∏è IMAGE ICON SIZE: Custom image icons should be 24x24px or 32x32px for optimal display
‚ö†Ô∏è AUTOCOMPLETE: Always use autoComplete='email' for better UX (browser autofill)
‚ö†Ô∏è ATTRIBUTE NAME: Image icon uses 'ButtonImage', not 'emailImage' or 'iconImage'
commonMistakes: ‚ùå Forgetting to set iconType before adding icon (icons won't appear)
‚ùå Using iconType='image' but providing 'emailImage' instead of 'ButtonImage' (attribute name is ButtonImage)
‚ùå Setting hlpTxt=false but adding desctxt (help text won't show)
‚ùå Using inpSz=50% for inline button (leaves no room for button - use 68-70% instead)
‚ùå Not setting autoComplete='email' (missing out on browser autofill UX)
‚ùå Expecting icon color change with image icons (only works with fontAwesome)
‚ùå Not testing responsive widths on mobile (fields should be full-width on xs breakpoint)
‚ùå Using generic error message 'Required' instead of specific 'Please enter a valid email address'
‚ùå Placing email field outside tp-form-block parent (block won't render correctly)
‚ùå Forgetting nxt-btn-inline class on submit button for inline layout
‚ùå Setting reqTgl=false for newsletter signups (email should always be required)
bestPractices: ‚úÖ Always set autoComplete='email' for better UX (browser autofill saves user time)
‚úÖ Keep labels concise: 'Email' or 'Email Address' not 'Please Enter Your Email Address Here'
‚úÖ Use placeholders for format guidance: 'your@email.com' or 'name@company.com'
‚úÖ Add help text for privacy-conscious forms: 'We'll never share your email'
‚úÖ Position help text strategically: 'bottom' for privacy notes, 'top' for instructions
‚úÖ Use icons consistently across form (if email has icon, name/phone should too)
‚úÖ Choose icons that match context: fa-envelope for general, fa-at for modern, fa-briefcase for business
‚úÖ Provide clear, specific error messages: 'A valid email address is required' not 'Error'
‚úÖ Make email fields full-width on mobile (inpSz.xs = '100')
‚úÖ For inline button layouts, use 68-70% width on desktop, 100% on mobile
‚úÖ Always set reqTgl=true for email fields (email is usually required)
‚úÖ Use descPoss='bottom' for help text by default (doesn't interfere with label reading flow)
‚úÖ For newsletter signups, include unsubscribe mention in help text (builds trust)
‚úÖ Test email validation with various formats (gmail.com, custom domains, plus addressing)
‚úÖ For business contexts, use placeholder like 'name@company.com' to set expectations
‚úÖ Combine icon + hover color for polished modern forms

autocompleteGuide.description: HTML autocomplete attribute values for email fields

off.useCase: Security-sensitive forms, unique identifiers (not recommended for most cases)

bestPractices: ‚úÖ Always use 'email' for email fields (improves UX)
‚ùå Don't use 'off' unless absolutely necessary (degrades UX)
Browser autofill increases form completion rates by 30-40%

iconTypeGuide.description: Icon display options for email fields

fontAwesome.useCase: Most common - wide icon selection, color customization

image.useCase: Branded forms, custom designs, specific graphics
notes: Recommended size: 24x24px or 32x32px
Supports PNG, JPG, SVG, WebP
SVG recommended for scalability and color control
No color customization via icnClr (use SVG fill for color)
Attribute name is 'ButtonImage', not 'emailImage'

fullWidth.useCase: Most common pattern for standalone email fields

inlineButton.description: Email field with inline submit button on same row
inlineButton.useCase: Newsletter signups, footer email collection, hero CTAs
notes: 68% email + 30% button + 2% gap = 100%
Submit button needs nxt-btn-inline class
Button stacks below on mobile (sm/xs)
Parent tp-form-block layoutType should be nxt-newsstyle-1, nxt-newsstyle-3, or nxt-newsstyle-4

halfWidthDesktop.description: Half-width on desktop, full-width on mobile
halfWidthDesktop.useCase: Multi-column forms (email + phone on same row)
notes: 48% allows for ~4% gap between fields on desktop
Parent tp-form-block controls gap spacing via columnGap

emailValidationGuide.description: Understanding automatic email validation in nxt-email-field

automaticValidation.description: Email fields have built-in browser validation
rules: Must have valid domain after @ (e.g., example.com)
Cannot start or end with @ or .
Must have at least one character before @

customValidation.description: Additional validation can be handled by parent tp-form-block
parentAttributes: failMsg: Message shown on validation failure
notes: Built-in validation only checks format, not if email exists
Cannot validate business vs personal email (requires custom server-side logic)
Cannot block disposable email domains without custom validation

accessibilityNotes: üåê WCAG 2.1 AA Compliance:
- Label must be descriptive and associated with input (labelss attribute)
- Error messages should be specific and actionable (error attribute)
- Required fields marked with asterisk (*) via reqTgl
- Help text provides additional context for screen readers (desctxt)
- Placeholder text supplements label, doesn't replace it
- autocomplete='email' improves assistive technology experience
üéØ Focus States:
- Parent tp-form-block controls focus styling (actInpBg, actInpBdr)
- Ensure focus state has 3:1 contrast ratio with background
‚å®Ô∏è Keyboard Navigation:
- Tab key moves between fields naturally
- Enter key submits form (handled by parent tp-form-block)
üîä Screen Reader Considerations:
- Label read first: 'Email Address, required, edit text'
- Help text read as description
- Error message announced on validation failure: 'Invalid entry, A valid email address is required'
- Icon decorative only (not announced)
üåà Color Contrast:
- Label text must have 4.5:1 contrast with background
- Placeholder text must have 4.5:1 contrast
- Icon color (icnClr) should have 3:1 contrast if conveying information
- Error messages typically red, but must have sufficient contrast (4.5:1)
üìß Email-Specific Accessibility:
- Always include 'Email' or 'Email Address' in label (don't just use icon)
- Error messages should clarify format: 'Please enter a valid email address like name@example.com'
- Help text can explain why email is needed: 'for account recovery' or 'to send confirmation'

parentChildRelationship.requirement: CRITICAL - nxt-email-field MUST be inside tp-form-block
parentControls: Input styling (inpClr, plcClr, inpBg, hvrInpBg, actInpBg, inpBdr, inpBdrRds, inpPad, inpTypo)
Help text styling (typically inherits from parent typography)
workflow: 2. Configure parent form action (Email, Mailchimp, etc.)
6. Email value automatically used in form submission via [nxt_email] placeholder

emailPlaceholder.description: Email field value can be used in parent tp-form-block email templates
usage: emailTo1: Use [nxt_email] to send copy to user
Email body: Use [nxt_email] to include user's email in message
Subject: Use [nxt_email] to personalize subject line

example.description: Sends confirmation email to user's entered email address

mailchimp.description: Collecting email for Mailchimp newsletter subscription
notes: Email value automatically sent to Mailchimp on form submit
No additional configuration needed in child block
Can combine with name field for better Mailchimp data

emailNotification.description: Sending email notification with user's email
notes: replyTo set to [nxt_email] allows direct reply to user
Can use [nxt_email] in email body to show user's email
Can send copy to user with emailTo2: '[nxt_email]'
